Award.AwardTitle: Oxidation of KCNB1 Channels in Aging CNS
Award.AbstractNarration:
The brain encodes information in the form of electrical impulses called action potentials that are continuously exchanged between neurons. As brains age, the transmission of Action Potentials becomes less efficient. It is not understood why this occurs, but one possibility is that over time, neurons accumulate highly toxic molecules known as reactive oxygen species (ROS). There is support for the idea that ROS oxidize potassium channel proteins whose function is to permit movement of potassium ions through the membranes of neurons. Potassium ion movements are involved in the propagation of action potentials by neurons. This project will directly test the hypothesis that oxidation of potassium channels by ROS leads to cognitive impairment by hindering the transmission of Action Potentials. The PI will integrate research activities and outcomes into formal lectures on the neuroscience of aging. The project will provide research training opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, underrepresented and summer students. The Principal Investigator will present a series of lectures to middle and high school students as part of the Science, Medicine and Related Topics (SMART) program, whose mission is to advance the understanding and appreciation of science among underrepresented students.

The KCNB1 potassium channel is abundantly expressed in the brain and is susceptible to oxidation by ROS. When a cysteine residue is replaced with an alanine (C73A), oxidation is abolished. Based on this observation, a transgenic mouse expressing the non-oxidable KCNB1 variant (C73A) has been constructed. The effects of ROS on KCNB1 channels and the impact of this process on cognitive function will be determined by studying cognitive function in aging C73A mice. Behavioral tests will be performed to see whether the lack of oxidation of KCNB1 improves the ability of mice to learn and remember new tasks. Changes in behavior will be correlated with changes in the electrical activity of the brain which will be recorded using state of the art electrophysiological techniques. Further, it will be determined whether the naturally occurring antioxidant, hydrogen sulfide, which is synthesized by neurons, can prevent oxidation of KCNB1 channels. It is expected that aging mice that harbor the C73A variant will exhibit less cognitive impairment and more normal electrical activity in cortex and hippocampus, two regions of the brain that are most affected by the activity of KCNB1.

Institution.Name: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey-RBHS-Robert Wood
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

Performance_Institution.Name: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey-RBHS-Robert Wood

POR.DRECONTENT:
To communicate, neurons use gates, called ion channels, that convey electrically charged atoms, or ions, in and out of cells. The flux of ions generates electricity, that is at the basis of may functions of the brain, including cognition. As neurons age, they begin to produce oxidants in excess, which damage the cell. By attacking ion channels, oxidants may affect electrical conduction and consequently deteriorate cognition. Indeed, our studies show that oxidants impair a specific type of ion channel, called potassium channel. This channel works in the neurons of the hippocampus, a region of the brain important for learning and memory. When oxidants attack this channel they cause loss of memory in mice. Protecting the channel enforces memory. Overall, oxidation of potassium channels represents an important mechanism of the aging process. It is active any time there are oxidants in excess, not only in the aging brain but also in diseases such as Alzheimer's disease and acute trauma. The negative effects of oxidation can be neutralized by a drug that is used to treat leukemia. This drug works well in mice and it is possible that it might work in humans. This project could have not been possible without the contribution and enthusiasm of the many undergraduate students that worked and were trained in the lab. They were exposed to prominent areas of research along with wide spectrum of state of the art techniques and most of them were consequently very successful (the majority went either to medical school or were admitted to graduate programs). Not only those students were stimulated to formulate new ideas that encouraged their creative thinking but they also disseminated the findings of their work to meetings and conferences. Our studies were featured in both scientific and non-scientific magazines and we hosted US Sen. Bob Menendez to take a tour of the lab where we showed him our findings about the impact that oxidation of potassium channels play in Alzheimer's disease and brain trauma (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HTWBZlxIAjY and http://www.njtvonline.org/news/video/sen-menendez-praises-rutgers-alzheimers-research/)

The flux of ions generates electricity, that is at the basis of may functions of the brain, including cognition. As neurons age, they begin to produce oxidants in excess, which damage the cell. By attacking ion channels, oxidants may affect electrical conduction and consequently deteriorate cognition. Indeed, our studies show that oxidants impair a specific type of ion channel, called potassium channel. This channel works in the neurons of the hippocampus, a region of the brain important for learning and memory. When oxidants attack this channel they cause loss of memory in mice. Protecting the channel enforces memory. Overall, oxidation of potassium channels represents an important mechanism of the aging process. It is active any time there are oxidants in excess, not only in the aging brain but also in diseases such as Alzheimer's disease and acute trauma. The negative effects of oxidation can be neutralized by a drug that is used to treat leukemia. This drug works well in mice and it is possible that it might work in humans. This project could have not been possible without the contribution and enthusiasm of the many undergraduate students that worked and were trained in the lab. They were exposed to prominent areas of research along with wide spectrum of state of the art techniques and most of them were consequently very successful (the majority went either to medical school or were admitted to graduate programs). Not only those students were stimulated to formulate new ideas that encouraged their creative thinking but they also disseminated the findings of their work to meetings and conferences.
